[[4]](#cite_note-Samp2006-4) [[5]](#cite_note-Tint10-5) It typically causes more than one of the following: an itchy rash, throat closing due to swelling which can obstruct or stop breathing; severe tongue swelling which can also interfere with or stop breathing; [shortness of breath](/wiki/Shortness_of_breath), [vomiting](/wiki/Vomiting), shock](/wiki/Shock_(circulatory)). [[6]](#cite_note-Overview_-_Anaphylaxis-6) [[1]](#cite_note-NIH2015-1) These symptoms typically start in minutes to hours and then increase very rapidly to life-threatening levels. [[1]](#cite_note-NIH2015-1) Urgent medical treatment is required to prevent serious harm or death, even if the patient has used an [epipen](/wiki/Epipen) or has taken other medications in response, and even if symptoms appear to be improving. [[6]](#cite_note-Overview_-_Anaphylaxis-6) Common causes include allergies to [insect bites](/wiki/Insect_bite) and stings, [allergies to foods](/wiki/Food_allergy) - including nuts, milk, fish, shellfish, eggs and some fresh fruits or dried fruits; allergies to sulfites - a class of food preservatives and a byproduct in some fermented foods like vinegar; allergies to medications - including some antibiotics and non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) like aspirin; allergy to general anaesthetic (used to make people sleep during surgery); allergy to contrast agents - dyes used in some medical tests to help certain areas of the body show up better on scans; allergy to [latex](/wiki/Latex) - a type of rubber found in some rubber gloves and condoms. [[6]](#cite_note-Overview_-_Anaphylaxis-6) [[1]](#cite_note-NIH2015-1) Other causes can include physical exercise, and cases may also occur in some people due to escalating reactions to simple throat irritation or may also occur without an obvious reason. [[6]](#cite_note-Overview_-_Anaphylaxis-6) [[1]](#cite_note-NIH2015-1) The mechanism involves the release of inflammatory mediators in a rapidly escalating cascade from certain types of [white blood cells](/wiki/White_blood_cell) triggered by either [immunologic](/wiki/Immune_system) or non-immunologic mechanisms. [[7]](#cite_note-Khan11-7) Diagnosis is based on the presenting symptoms and signs after exposure to a potential [allergen](/wiki/Allergen) or irritant and in some cases, reaction to physical exercise. [[6]](#cite_note-Overview_-_Anaphylaxis-6) [[1]](#cite_note-NIH2015-1) The primary treatment of anaphylaxis is [epinephrine](/wiki/Epinephrine_(medication)) [injection a muscle](/wiki/Intramuscular), [intravenous fluids](/wiki/Intravenous_fluid), then placing the person "in a reclining position with feet elevated to help restore normal blood flow". [[1]](#cite_note-NIH2015-1) [[8]](#cite_note-EAACI2014-8) Additional doses of epinephrine may be required. [[1]](#cite_note-NIH2015-1) Other measures, such as [antihistamines](/wiki/Antihistamine) and [steroids](/wiki/Corticosteroids), are complementary. [[1]](#cite_note-NIH2015-1) Carrying an [epinephrine autoinjector](/wiki/Epinephrine_autoinjector), commonly called an "epipen" and identification regarding the condition is recommended in people with a history of anaphylaxis. [[1]](#cite_note-NIH2015-1) Immediately contacting ambulance / EMT services is always strongly recommended, regardless of any on site treatment. [[6]](#cite_note-Overview_-_Anaphylaxis-6) Getting to a doctor or hospital as soon as possible is absolutely required in all cases, even if it appears to be getting better. [[6]](#cite_note-Overview_-_Anaphylaxis-6) Worldwide, 0.05-2% of the population is estimated to experience anaphylaxis at some point in life. [[3]](#cite_note-World11-3) Globally, as underreporting declined into the 2010s, the rate appeared to be increasing. [[3]](#cite_note-World11-3) It occurs most often in young people and females. [[8]](#cite_note-EAACI2014-8) [[9]](#cite_note-CEA11-9) About 99.7% of people hospitalized with anaphylaxis in the United States survive. [[10]](#cite_note-10) Etymology[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Anaphylaxis&action=edit§ion=1)] The many different symptoms over minutes or hours [[8]](#cite_note-EAACI2014-8) [[12]](#cite_note-12) with an average onset of 5 to 30 minutes if exposure is intravenous and up to 2 hours if from eating food. [[13]](#cite_note-Rosen2010-13) The most common areas affected include: [gastrointestinal](/wiki/Human_gastrointestinal_tract) nervous system (10-15%) [[14]](#cite_note-Review09-14) with usually two or more being involved. [[3]](#cite_note-World11-3) Skin[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Anaphylaxis&action=edit§ion=3)] Symptoms [[4]](#cite_note-Samp2006-4) Those with angioedema may describe a burning sensation of the skin rather than itchiness. [[13]](#cite_note-Rosen2010-13) Swelling of the tongue or throat occurs in up to about 20% of cases. [[15]](#cite_note-Shock10-15) Other features may include a runny nose and swelling of the [conjunctiva](/wiki/Conjunctiva). [[16]](#cite_note-Aus06-16) The skin may also be [lack of oxygen](/wiki/Hypoxia_(medical)). [[16]](#cite_note-Aus06-16) Respiratory[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Anaphylaxis&action=edit§ion=4)] Respiratory symptoms and signs that may present include [shortness of breath](/wiki/Dyspnea), [wheezes](/wiki/Wheeze), or [stridor](/wiki/Stridor). [[4]](#cite_note-Samp2006-4) The wheezing is typically caused by spasms of the [bronchial](/wiki/Bronchus) muscles [[17]](#cite_note-Cardio08-17) while stridor is related to upper airway obstruction secondary to swelling. [[16]](#cite_note-Aus06-16) Hoarseness, pain with swallowing, or a cough may also occur. [[13]](#cite_note-Rosen2010-13) Cardiovascular[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Anaphylaxis&action=edit§ion=5)] While [a fast heart rate](/wiki/Tachycardia) caused by low blood pressure is more common, [[16]](#cite_note-Aus06-16) a [Bezold-Jarisch reflex](/wiki/Bezold%E2%80%93Jarisch_reflex) has been described in 10% of people, where a [slow heart rate](/wiki/Bradycardia) is associated with [low blood pressure](/wiki/Hypotension). [blood pressure](/wiki/Blood_pressure) or [shock](/wiki/Shock_(circulatory)) (either [distributive](/wiki/Distributive_shock) or [cardiogenic](/wiki/Cardiogenic_shock)) may feeling of lightheadedness or [loss of consciousness](/wiki/Unconsciousness). [[17]](#cite_note-Cardio08-17) Rarely very low blood pressure may be the only sign of anaphylaxis. [[15]](#cite_note-Shock10-15) [Coronary artery spasm](/wiki/Angina_pectoris) [cardiac arrest](/wiki/Cardiac_arrest). [[3]](#cite_note-World11-3) [[14]](#cite_note-Review09-14) Those with underlying coronary disease are at greater risk of cardiac effects from anaphylaxis. [[17]](#cite_note-Cardio08-17) The coronary spasm is related to the presence of [histamine](/wiki/Histamine)-releasing cells in the heart. [[17]](#cite_note-Cardio08-17) Other[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Anaphylaxis&action=edit§ion=6)] Gastrointestinal symptoms include severe crampy [abdominal pain](/wiki/Abdominal_pain), diarrhea, and vomiting. [[4]](#cite_note-Samp2006-4) There may be confusion, a loss of bladder control or pelvic pain similar to that of [uterine](/wiki/Uterus) cramps. [[4]](#cite_note-Samp2006-4) [[16]](#cite_note-Aus06-16) Dilation of blood vessels around the brain may cause [headaches](/wiki/Headache). [[13]](#cite_note-Rosen2010-13) A feeling of [anxiety](/wiki/Anxiety_(mood)) or of also been described. [[3]](#cite_note-World11-3) Causes[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Anaphylaxis&action=edit§ion=7)] Anaphylaxis can occur in response to almost any foreign substance. [[18]](#cite_note-His11-18) Common triggers include [venom](/wiki/Venom) from [insect bites or stings](/wiki/Insect_bites_and_stings), foods, and [medication](/wiki/Pharmaceutical_drug). [[9]](#cite_note-CEA11-9) [[19]](#cite_note-19) Foods are the most common trigger in children and young adults, while medications and insect bites and stings are more common in older adults. [[3]](#cite_note-World11-3) Less common causes include: physical factors, biological agents such as [semen](/wiki/Semen), [latex](/wiki/Latex), [hormonal](/wiki/Hormone) changes, food additives and colors, and topical medications. [[16]](#cite_note-Aus06-16) Physical factors such as exercise (known as [exercise-induced anaphylaxis](/wiki/Exercise-induced_anaphylaxis)) or temperature (either hot or cold) may also act as triggers through their direct effects on [mast cells](/wiki/Mast_cell). [[3]](#cite_note-World11-3) [[20]](#cite_note-APLS07-20) [[21]](#cite_note-21) Events caused by exercise are frequently associated with cofactors such as the ingestion of certain foods [[13]](#cite_note-Rosen2010-13) [[22]](#cite_note-Pravetton2016rev-22) or taking an [NSAID](/wiki/NSAID). [[22]](#cite_note-Pravetton2016rev-22) In [aspirin-exacerbated During [anesthesia](/wiki/Anesthesia), [neuromuscular blocking agents](/wiki/Neuromuscular-blocking_drug), [antibiotics](/wiki/Antibacterial), and latex are the most common causes. [[25]](#cite_note-25) The cause remains unknown in 32-50% of cases, referred to as " [idiopathic](/wiki/Idiopathic) anaphylaxis." [[26]](#cite_note-editor_2010_223-26) Six vaccines (MMR, varicella, influenza, hepatitis B, tetanus, meningococcal) are recognized as a cause for anaphylaxis, and [HPV](/wiki/Human_papillomavirus) may cause anaphylaxis as well. [[27]](#cite_note-27) Food and alcohol[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Anaphylaxis&action=edit§ion=8)] Many foods can trigger anaphylaxis; this may occur upon the first known ingestion. [[9]](#cite_note-CEA11-9) Common triggering foods vary around the world due to cultural cuisine. In Western cultures, ingestion of or exposure to [peanuts](/wiki/Peanut), [wheat](/wiki/Wheat), [nuts](/wiki/Nut_(fruit)), certain types of [seafood](/wiki/Seafood) like [shellfish](/wiki/Shellfish), are the most prevalent causes. [[3]](#cite_note-World11-3) [[14]](#cite_note-Review09-14) [Sesame](/wiki/Sesame) is common in the Middle East, while rice and [chickpeas](/wiki/Chickpea) are frequently encountered as sources of anaphylaxis in Asia. [[3]](#cite_note-World11-3) Severe cases are usually caused by ingesting the allergen, [[9]](#cite_note-CEA11-9) but some people experience a severe reaction upon contact. Children can outgrow their allergies. By age 16, 80% of children with anaphylaxis to milk or eggs and 20% who experience isolated anaphylaxis to peanuts can tolerate these foods. [[18]](#cite_note-His11-18) Any type of alcohol, even in small amounts, can trigger anaphylaxis in people with AERD. [[23]](#cite_note-Stevens2015-23) [[24]](#cite_note-Cardet2014-24) Medication[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Anaphylaxis&action=edit§ion=9)] Any medication may potentially trigger The most common are [-lactam antibiotics](/wiki/%CE%92-lactam_antibiotic) (such as by [aspirin](/wiki/Aspirin) and Other implicated [[28]](#cite_note-WHO2015-28) Anaphylactic reactions to NSAIDs are either agent specific or occur among those that are structurally similar meaning that those who are allergic to one NSAID can typically tolerate a different one or different group of NSAIDs. [[29]](#cite_note-29) Other relatively common causes include [chemotherapy](/wiki/Chemotherapy), contrast](/wiki/Radiocontrast_agent) anaphylaxis by directly triggering mast cell [degranulation](/wiki/Degranulation). [[9]](#cite_note-CEA11-9) The frequency of a reaction to an agent partly depends on the frequency of its use and partly on its intrinsic properties. [[30]](#cite_note-Drug01-30) Anaphylaxis to penicillin or [cephalosporins](/wiki/Cephalosporin) occurs only after it binds to proteins inside the body with some agents binding more easily than others. [[13]](#cite_note-Rosen2010-13) Anaphylaxis to penicillin occurs once in every 2,000 to 10,000 courses of treatment, with death occurring in fewer than one in every 50,000 courses of treatment. [[13]](#cite_note-Rosen2010-13) Anaphylaxis to aspirin and NSAIDs occurs in about one in every 50,000 persons. [[13]](#cite_note-Rosen2010-13) If someone has a reaction to penicillin, his or her risk of a reaction to cephalosporins is greater but still less than one in 1,000. [[13]](#cite_note-Rosen2010-13) The old radiocontrast agents caused reactions in 1% of cases, while the newer lower osmolar agents cause reactions in 0.04% of cases. [[30]](#cite_note-Drug01-30) Venom[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Anaphylaxis&action=edit§ion=10)] [Venom](/wiki/Venom) from stinging or biting insects such as [Hymenoptera](/wiki/Hymenoptera) (ants, bees, and wasps) or [Triatominae](/wiki/Triatominae) (kissing bugs) may cause anaphylaxis in susceptible people. [[8]](#cite_note-EAACI2014-8) [[31]](#cite_note-Klotz-31) [[32]](#cite_note-2001simonga-32) Previous reactions that are anything more than a local reaction around the site of the sting, are a risk factor for future anaphylaxis; [[33]](#cite_note-33) [[34]](#cite_note-34) however, half of fatalities have had no previous systemic reaction. [[35]](#cite_note-35) Risk factors[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Anaphylaxis&action=edit§ion=11)] People with [atopic](/wiki/Atopy) diseases such as [asthma](/wiki/Asthma), [eczema](/wiki/Eczema), or [allergic rhinitis](/wiki/Allergic_rhinitis) are at high risk of anaphylaxis from food, [latex](/wiki/Latex), and [radiocontrast agents](/wiki/Radiocontrast_agent) but not from injectable medications or stings. [[3]](#cite_note-World11-3) [[9]](#cite_note-CEA11-9) One study in children found that 60% had a history of previous atopic diseases, and of children who die from anaphylaxis, more than 90% have asthma. [[9]](#cite_note-CEA11-9) Those with [mastocytosis](/wiki/Mastocytosis) or of a higher [socioeconomic at increased is a affecting many [body systems](/wiki/Biological_system). [[5]](#cite_note-Tint10-5) [[7]](#cite_note-Khan11-7) It is due to the release of [inflammatory mediators](/wiki/Inflammation) and [cytokines](/wiki/Cytokine) from mast cells and [basophils](/wiki/Basophil_granulocyte), typically due to an [immunologic reaction](/wiki/Immune_system) but [[7]](#cite_note-Khan11-7) [Interleukin](/wiki/Interleukin) (IL)-4 and IL-13 are cytokines important in the initial generation of antibody and inflammatory cell responses to anaphylaxis.[ [citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed)] Immunologic[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Anaphylaxis&action=edit§ion=13)] In (IgE) binds to the [antigen](/wiki/Antigen) (the foreign material that provokes the allergic reaction). Antigen-bound IgE then activates [FcRI](/wiki/Fc%CE%B5RI) receptors on mast cells and basophils. This leads to the release of inflammatory mediators such as [histamine](/wiki/Histamine). These mediators subsequently increase the contraction of bronchial [smooth muscles](/wiki/Smooth_muscle_tissue), trigger [vasodilation](/wiki/Vasodilation), increase the leakage of fluid from blood vessels, and cause heart muscle depression. [[7]](#cite_note-Khan11-7) [[13]](#cite_note-Rosen2010-13) There is also a non-immunologic mechanism that does not rely on IgE, but it is not known if this occurs in humans. [[7]](#cite_note-Khan11-7) Non-immunologic[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Anaphylaxis&action=edit§ion=14)] Non-immunologic mechanisms involve substances that directly cause the [degranulation](/wiki/Degranulation) of mast cells and basophils. These include agents such as [contrast medium](/wiki/Contrast_medium), [opioids](/wiki/Opioid), temperature (hot or cold), and vibration. [[7]](#cite_note-Khan11-7) [[20]](#cite_note-APLS07-20) [Sulfites](/wiki/Sulfites) may cause reactions mechanisms. [[36]](#cite_note-36) Diagnosis[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Anaphylaxis&action=edit§ion=15)] Anaphylaxis is diagnosed on the basis of a person's signs and symptoms. [[3]](#cite_note-World11-3) When any one of the following three occurs within minutes or hours of exposure to an allergen there is a high likelihood of anaphylaxis: [[3]](#cite_note-World11-3) - Involvement of the skin or mucosal tissue plus either [respiratory difficulty](/wiki/Respiratory_distress)or a low [blood pressure](/wiki/Blood_pressure)causing symptoms - Two or more of the following symptoms after a likely contact with an allergen: - a. Involvement of the skin or [mucosa](/wiki/Mucous_membrane) - b. [Respiratory difficulties](/wiki/Respiratory_distress) - c. [Low blood pressure](/wiki/Hypotension) - d. [Gastrointestinal](/wiki/Human_gastrointestinal_tract)symptoms - a. Involvement of the skin or - Low blood pressure after exposure to a known allergen Skin involvement may include: hives, itchiness or a swollen tongue among others. Respiratory difficulties may include: shortness of breath, [stridor](/wiki/Stridor), or low oxygen levels among others. Low blood pressure is defined as a greater than 30% decrease from a person's usual blood pressure. In adults a systolic blood pressure of less than 90 mmHg is often used. [[3]](#cite_note-World11-3) During an attack, blood tests for [tryptase](/wiki/Tryptase) or [histamine](/wiki/Histamine) (released from mast cells) might be useful in diagnosing anaphylaxis due to insect stings or medications. However these tests are of limited use if the cause is food or if the person has a normal [blood pressure](/wiki/Blood_pressure), [[3]](#cite_note-World11-3) and they are not [specific](/wiki/Sensitivity_and_specificity) for the diagnosis. [[18]](#cite_note-His11-18) Classification[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Anaphylaxis&action=edit§ion=16)] There are three main classifications of anaphylaxis. - Anaphylactic shock is associated with systemic [vasodilation](/wiki/Vasodilation)that causes [low blood pressure](/wiki/Hypotension)which is by definition 30% lower than the person's baseline or below standard values. [[15]](#cite_note-Shock10-15) - Biphasic anaphylaxis is the recurrence of symptoms within 1-72 hours after resolution of an initial anaphylactic episode. [[37]](#cite_note-pmid32001253-37)Estimates of incidence vary, between less than 1% and up to 20% of cases. [[37]](#cite_note-pmid32001253-37) [[38]](#cite_note-BI05-38)The recurrence typically occurs within 8 hours. [[9]](#cite_note-CEA11-9)It is managed in the same manner as anaphylaxis. [[8]](#cite_note-EAACI2014-8) - Anaphylactoid reaction, non-immune anaphylaxis, or pseudoanaphylaxis, is a type of anaphylaxis that does not involve an allergic reaction but is due to direct mast cell degranulation. [[9]](#cite_note-CEA11-9) [[39]](#cite_note-His10-39)Non-immune anaphylaxis is the current term, as of 2018, used by the [World Allergy Organization](/wiki/World_Allergy_Organization) [[39]](#cite_note-His10-39)with some recommending that the old terminology, "anaphylactoid", no longer be used. [[9]](#cite_note-CEA11-9) Allergy skin testing[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Anaphylaxis&action=edit§ion=17)] [Allergy testing](/wiki/Allergy_test) may help in determining the trigger. [Skin allergy testing](/wiki/Skin_allergy_test) is available for certain foods and venoms. [[18]](#cite_note-His11-18) Blood testing for specific [IgE](/wiki/IgE) can be useful to confirm milk, egg, peanut, tree nut and fish allergies. [[18]](#cite_note-His11-18) Skin testing is available to confirm [penicillin](/wiki/Penicillin) allergies, but is not available for other medications. [[18]](#cite_note-His11-18) Non-immune forms of anaphylaxis can only be determined by history or exposure to the allergen in question, and not by skin or blood testing. [[39]](#cite_note-His10-39) Differential diagnosis[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Anaphylaxis&action=edit§ion=18)] It can sometimes be difficult anaphylaxis from [asthma](/wiki/Asthma), [syncope](/wiki/Syncope_(medicine)), and [panic attacks](/wiki/Panic_attack). [[3]](#cite_note-World11-3) Asthma however typically does not entail itching or gastrointestinal symptoms, syncope presents with pallor rather than a rash, and a panic attack may have flushing but does not have hives. [[3]](#cite_note-World11-3) Other conditions that may present similarly include: [scrombroidosis](/wiki/Scombroid_food_poisoning) and [anisakiasis](/wiki/Anisakis#Anisakiasis). [[9]](#cite_note-CEA11-9) Post-mortem anaphylaxis, [autopsy](/wiki/Autopsy) may show an "empty heart" attributed to reduced venous return from [vasodilation](/wiki/Vasodilation) and redistribution of intravascular volume from the central to the peripheral compartment. [[40]](#cite_note-40) Other signs are laryngeal edema, eosinophilia in lungs, heart and tissues, and evidence of myocardial hypoperfusion. [[41]](#cite_note-DaBroi-41) Laboratory findings could detect increased levels of serum [tryptase](/wiki/Tryptase), increase in total and specific IgE serum levels. [[41]](#cite_note-DaBroi-41) Prevention[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Anaphylaxis&action=edit§ion=20)] Avoidance of the trigger of anaphylaxis is recommended. In cases where this may not be possible, desensitization may be an option. [Immunotherapy](/wiki/Immunotherapy) with [Hymenoptera](/wiki/Hymenoptera) venoms is effective at desensitizing 80-90% of adults and 98% of children [wasps](/wiki/Wasp), [hornets](/wiki/Hornet), [yellowjackets](/wiki/Yellow_jacket), [fire ants](/wiki/Fire_ant). Oral immunotherapy may be effective at desensitizing some people to certain food including milk, eggs, nuts and peanuts; however, adverse effects are common. [[3]](#cite_note-World11-3) For example, many people develop an itchy throat, cough, or lip swelling during immunotherapy. [[42]](#cite_note-42) Desensitization is also possible for many medications, however it is advised that most people simply avoid the agent in question. In those who react to latex it may be important to avoid cross-reactive foods such as avocados, bananas, and potatoes among others. [[3]](#cite_note-World11-3) Management[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Anaphylaxis&action=edit§ion=21)] Anaphylaxis is a [medical [supplemental oxygen](/wiki/Oxygen_therapy), monitoring. [[8]](#cite_note-EAACI2014-8) [Passive leg raise](/wiki/Passive_leg_raise) may also be helpful in the emergency management. [[43]](#cite_note-Simons_2010_pp._S161-S181-43) Administration of intravenous fluid bolus and epinephrine is the treatment of choice with [antihistamines](/wiki/Histamine_antagonist) used as adjuncts. [[44]](#cite_note-44) A period of in-hospital observation for between 2 and 24 hours is recommended for people once they have returned to normal due to concerns 1,000) is the primary treatment for anaphylaxis with no absolute [contraindication](/wiki/Contraindication) to its use. [[8]](#cite_note-EAACI2014-8) It is recommended that an epinephrine solution be given [intramuscularly](/wiki/Intramuscular_injection) into the mid anterolateral thigh as soon as the diagnosis is suspected. The injection may be repeated every 5 to 15 minutes if there is insufficient response. [[8]](#cite_note-EAACI2014-8) A second dose is needed in 16-35% of episodes with more than two doses rarely required. [[8]](#cite_note-EAACI2014-8) The intramuscular route is preferred over [subcutaneous](/wiki/Subcutaneous_tissue) administration because the latter may have delayed absorption. [[8]](#cite_note-EAACI2014-8) [[46]](#cite_note-Epi10-46) It is recommended that after diagnosis and treatment of anaphylaxis, the patient should be kept under observation in an appropriate clinical setting until symptoms have fully resolved. [[37]](#cite_note-pmid32001253-37) Minor adverse effects from epinephrine include [tremors](/wiki/Tremor), anxiety, headaches, and [palpitations](/wiki/Palpitation). [[3]](#cite_note-World11-3) People on [-blockers](/wiki/Beta_blocker) may be resistant to the effects of epinephrine. [[9]](#cite_note-CEA11-9) In this situation if epinephrine is not effective intravenous [glucagon](/wiki/Glucagon) can be administered which has a mechanism of action independent of [-receptors](/wiki/Adrenergic_receptor). [[9]](#cite_note-CEA11-9) If necessary, it can also be given [intravenously](/wiki/Intravenous_therapy) using a dilute epinephrine solution. Intravenous epinephrine, however, infarction](/wiki/Myocardial_infarction). [[8]](#cite_note-EAACI2014-8) [Epinephrine autoinjectors](/wiki/Epinephrine_autoinjector) used for self-administration typically come in two doses, one for adults or children who weigh more than 25 kg and one for children who weigh 10 to 25 kg. [[47]](#cite_note-47) Adjuncts[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Anaphylaxis&action=edit§ion=23)] [Antihistamines](/wiki/Histamine_antagonist) (both [H1](/wiki/H1_antagonist) and [H2](/wiki/H2_antagonist)), while commonly used and assumed effective based on theoretical reasoning, are poorly supported by evidence. [[48]](#cite_note-48) [[49]](#cite_note-She2007-49) A 2007 [Cochrane](/wiki/Cochrane_Collaboration) review did not find any good-quality studies upon which to base recommendations [[49]](#cite_note-She2007-49) and they are not believed to have an effect on airway edema or spasm. [[9]](#cite_note-CEA11-9) [Corticosteroids](/wiki/Corticosteroids) are unlikely to make a difference in the current episode of anaphylaxis, but may be used in the hope of decreasing the risk of biphasic anaphylaxis. Their prophylactic effectiveness in these situations is uncertain. [[38]](#cite_note-BI05-38) [Nebulized](/wiki/Nebulizer) [salbutamol](/wiki/Salbutamol) may be effective for [bronchospasm](/wiki/Bronchospasm) that does not resolve with epinephrine. [[9]](#cite_note-CEA11-9) [Methylene blue](/wiki/Methylene_blue) has been used in those not responsive to other measures due to its presumed effect of relaxing smooth muscle. [[9]](#cite_note-CEA11-9) Preparedness[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Anaphylaxis&action=edit§ion=24)] People prone to anaphylaxis are advised to have an allergy action plan. Parents are advised to inform schools of their children's allergies and what to do in case of an anaphylactic emergency. The action plan usually includes use of [epinephrine autoinjectors](/wiki/Epinephrine_autoinjector), the recommendation to wear a [medical alert bracelet](/wiki/Medical_identification_tag), and counseling on avoidance of triggers. [[50]](#cite_note-Mart08-50) [Immunotherapy](/wiki/Allergen_immunotherapy) is available for certain triggers to prevent future episodes of anaphylaxis. A multi-year course of subcutaneous [desensitization](/wiki/Desensitization_(medicine)) has been found effective against stinging insects, while oral desensitization is effective for many foods. [[14]](#cite_note-Review09-14) Prognosis[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Anaphylaxis&action=edit§ion=25)] In those in whom the cause is known and prompt treatment is available, the prognosis is good. [[51]](#cite_note-Harris2007-51) Even if the cause is unknown, if appropriate preventive medication is available, the prognosis is generally good. [[13]](#cite_note-Rosen2010-13) Usually death occurs usually due to either respiratory failure (typically involving [asphyxia](/wiki/Asphyxia)) or cardiovascular complications, such as [cardiovascular shock](/wiki/Cardiovascular_shock), [[7]](#cite_note-Khan11-7) [[9]](#cite_note-CEA11-9) with 0.7-20% of cases causing death. [[13]](#cite_note-Rosen2010-13) [[17]](#cite_note-Cardio08-17) There have been cases of death occurring within minutes. [[3]](#cite_note-World11-3) Outcomes in those with exercise-induced anaphylaxis are typically good, with fewer and less severe episodes as people get older. [[26]](#cite_note-editor_2010_223-26) Epidemiology[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Anaphylaxis&action=edit§ion=26)] The number of people who get anaphylaxis is 4-100 per 100,000 persons per year, [[9]](#cite_note-CEA11-9) a [lifetime risk](/wiki/Cumulative_incidence) of 0.05-2%. [[53]](#cite_note-53) About people get more than one attack. [[52]](#cite_note-Tej2015-52) Exercise-induced anaphylaxis affects about 1 in 2000 young people. [[22]](#cite_note-Pravetton2016rev-22) Rates appear to be increasing: the numbers in the 1980s were approximately 20 per 100,000 per year, while in the 1990s it was 50 per 100,000 per year. [[14]](#cite_note-Review09-14) The increase appears to be primarily for food-induced anaphylaxis. [[54]](#cite_note-54) The risk is greatest in young people and females. [[8]](#cite_note-EAACI2014-8) [[9]](#cite_note-CEA11-9) Anaphylaxis leads to as many as 500-1,000 deaths per year (2.7 per million) in the United States, 20 deaths per year in the United Kingdom (0.33 per million), and 15 deaths per year in Australia (0.64 per million). [[9]](#cite_note-CEA11-9) Another estimate from the United States puts the death rate at 0.7 per million. [[55]](#cite_note-55) Mortality rates have decreased between the 1970s and 2000s. [[56]](#cite_note-56) In Australia, death from food-induced anaphylaxis occur primarily in women while deaths due to insect bites primarily occur in males. [[9]](#cite_note-CEA11-9) Death from anaphylaxis is most commonly triggered by medications. [[9]](#cite_note-CEA11-9) History[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Anaphylaxis&action=edit§ion=27)] The conditions of anaphylaxis has been known since ancient times. [[39]](#cite_note-His10-39) French physician [François Magendie](/wiki/Fran%C3%A7ois_Magendie) had described how rabbits were killed by repeated injections of egg albumin in 1839. [[57]](#cite_note-57) However, the phenomenon was discovered French [Charles Richet](/wiki/Charles_Richet) and [Paul Portier](/wiki/Paul_Portier_(physiologist)). of Monaco](/wiki/Albert_I,_Prince_of_Monaco) requested Richet and Portier join him on a scientific expedition around the French coast of the Atlantic Ocean, [[59]](#cite_note-59) specifically to study on the toxin produced by cnidarians (like [jellyfish](/wiki/Jellyfish) and Albert's ship Princesse Alice II for ocean exploration to make collections of the marine animals. [[60]](#cite_note-:0-60) Richet and Portier extracted a toxin called hypnotoxin from their collection of jellyfish (but the real source was later identified as [Portuguese man [[62]](#cite_note-:2-62) In their first experiment on the ship, they injected a dog with the toxin in an attempt to immunise the dog, which instead developed a severe reaction ( [hypersensitivity](/wiki/Hypersensitivity)). In 1902, they repeated the injections in their laboratory and found that dogs normally tolerated the toxin at first injection, but on re-exposure, three weeks later with the same dose, they always developed fatal shock. They also found that the effect was not related to the doses of toxin used, as even small amounts in secondary injections were lethal. [[62]](#cite_note-:2-62) Thus, instead of inducing tolerance ( [prophylaxis](/wiki/Prophylaxis)) which they expected, they discovered effects of the toxin as deadly. [[63]](#cite_note-63) In 1902, Richet introduced the term aphylaxis to describe the condition of lack of protection. He later changed the term to anaphylaxis on grounds of [euphony](/wiki/Euphony). [[18]](#cite_note-His11-18) The term is from the [Greek](/wiki/Classical_Greek) "against", and February 1902, Richet and Portier jointly presented their findings before the Societé de Biologie in Paris. [[65]](#cite_note-65) [[66]](#cite_note-Ring_2014_54-61-66) The moment is regarded as the birth of allergy (the term invented by [Clemens von Pirquet](/wiki/Clemens_von_Pirquet) in 1906) study ( [allergology](/wiki/Allergology)). [[66]](#cite_note-Ring_2014_54-61-66) Richet continued to study on the phenomenon and was eventually awarded the [Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine](/wiki/Nobel_Prize_in_Physiology_or_Medicine) for his work on anaphylaxis in 1913.
